--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> The developers I work with are everyone who downloads my code. Some of 
> them I trust. Some of them I don't. They range in skill levels from 
> extremely experienced, wise, knowledgeable developers like Michael Kay 
> to random undergraduates and unreconstructed COBOL hacks.

So, to make it clear, you're building an API for external use, which
you have no control over.

> I promise that the 
> library behaves in a certain way under certain conditions and 
> accomplishes certain tasks. I can do this only because my libraries are 
> designed around concrete classes. Were the library designed around 
> interfaces instead, I could no no longer make such promises. 

As you said earlier, the conditions that you can promise this include
that no-one has been playing silly buggers with your code base. Why
can you not extend that to include that they should not write their
own implementations?

Furthermore, I would argue that by not providing interfaces, you may
well be making the life of the 3rd-party developers more difficult. 

Robert.
